A '''hereditary dictatorship''', or '''family dictatorship''', in political science terms a '''personalistic regime''', is a form of [[dictatorship]] that occurs in a nominally or formally [[republic]]an or [[Socialism|socialist]] regime, but operates in practice like an [[absolute monarchy]] or [[Despotism|despotate]], in that political power passes within the dictator's family. Thus, although the key leader is often called [[president]] or [[prime minister]] rather than a [[king]] or [[emperor]], power is transmitted between members of the same family due to the overwhelming authority of the leader. Sometimes the leader has been declared [[president for life]] and uses this power to nominate one of his or her family as successor.
A family dictatorship is different from a [[monarchy]] (where the descent is required by general constitutional law), or a [[political family]] (where members of the family possess informal, rather than formal and overwhelming political authority).
==Distinguishing features== A family dictatorship is different from an absolute monarchy, and the ruler does not usually base his or her authority on the concept of [[divine right of kings|divine right]]. In the latter, the transition of power within a family is required by general law as part of the state's constitutional arrangement, and continues to apply to all successions in the regime. In the former, this arrangement is not required by general law. In some cases, a special law might be enacted to formally nominate one particular family member of the present leader as the successor. In other cases, the law of the state may even formally provide for elections, but control exerted by the leader on the political and electoral process ensures a hereditary succession. Furthermore, whether each succession succeeds depends on the level of authority and control of the leader. As a result, modern family dictatorships often transition into a non-familial (non-personalistic) regime after a small number of successions: usually just one, and rarely more than two.
A family dictatorship is also different from other [[political family|political families]]. In the latter, informal power and influence accrued to the family enables the family to continue to hold political power, often through open and contested elections. In the former, the family uses either formal legal or political power or control to ensure a familial succession, and usually via a controlled or uncontested election, or no election at all.
Because a family dictatorship exerts significant control on its succession, a successor is often determined well in advance. However, because it often lacks a formal general law basis for the succession, there are often long periods of uncertainty as to the identity of the successor. As often happens in other types of [[totalitarianism|totalitarian]] regimes which plan their own succession, after a successor is determined or short-listed, they often go through a significant period of "grooming", in which the successor gains the experiences and qualifications aimed to make him or her attain the authority necessary to lead the regime.
==Successful transitions of power== [[File:Kim Jong-un at the Workers' Party of Korea main building.png|thumb|Kim Jong-Un, supreme leader of North Korea and member of the three-generation Kim dynasty is a prominent example of family dictatorship.]] Dates in parentheses denote the period of rule. <!-- Please sort this list by the start of the first ruling period --> ===Europe=== * [[Roman Republic]]: [[Julius Caesar|Gaius Julius Caesar]] (49–44 BCE) succeeded by his grand-nephew and adopted son [[Gaius Julius Caesar Octavianus]] (44–27 BCE). * [[Roman Empire]]: The early dynasties of the Roman Empire operated similarly to a family dictatorship. [[Augustus]] (27 BCE–14 CE) kept up the facade of a republic during his reign but designated his own successor, [[Tiberius]], by adopting Tiberius and convincing the [[Roman Senate|Senate]] to transfer his powers to Tiberius (14 CE–37 CE) upon his death. For three hundred years, subsequent emperors customarily designated their successor by adoption. From the reign of [[Diocletian]] (284–305) onwards, emperors ruled in an openly monarchic style. * [[Dutch Republic]]: [[Stadtholder|Stadtholders]] were chosen exclusively from the [[House of Orange-Nassau]]. In all, nine princes of this dynasty ruled the Republic from 1559 to 1795. Stadtholders were described as dictators by [[William Aglionby]] in his 1669 book, ''The Present State of the United Provinces of the Low-Countries''.<ref>Aglionby, William A. (1669), ''[https://quod.lib.umich.edu/e/eebo/A26549.0001.001?view=toc The Present State of the United Provinces of the Low-Countries]''. John Starkey.</ref> *[[Commonwealth of England]]: [[Oliver Cromwell]] (1653–1658) succeeded as [[Lord Protector]] of the [[Commonwealth of England|Commonwealth]] by his son [[Richard Cromwell]] (1658–1659). Richard Cromwell was overthrown by the army in Spring, 1659, leading to the restoration of King [[Charles II of England|Charles II]] the next year. *[[People's Socialist Republic of Albania|Albania]]: [[Enver Hoxha]] ([[Party of Labour of Albania|First Secretary of the Party of Labour]], 1944–1985; [[List of Prime Ministers of Albania|Prime Minister]], 1944–1954); succeeded by his wife [[Nexhmije Hoxha]] (1986–1990) as Chairwoman of the [[Democratic Front of Albania]].<ref>Elsie, Robert. ''Historical Dictionary of Albania''. Plymouth: Scarecrow Press, Inc. 2010. p. 195. Vickers, Miranda. ''The Albanians: A Modern History''. New York: I.B. Tauris & Co Ltd. 1999. p. 217.</ref> * [[Azerbaijan]]: [[Heydar Aliyev]] ([[President of Azerbaijan|President]], 1993–2003); succeeded by his son [[Ilham Aliyev]] (2003–present).
===Central and South America=== * [[History of Paraguay#Carlos Antonio López, 1841–62|Paraguay]]: [[Carlos Antonio López]] ([[President of Paraguay|President]], 1840–1862); succeeded by his son, [[Francisco Solano López]] (1862–1870) * [[El Salvador]]: [[Carlos Meléndez (politician)|Carlos Meléndez]] ([[President of El Salvador|President]], 1915–1918), succeeded by his brother [[Jorge Meléndez]] (1919–1923), succeeded by ''his'' brother-in-law [[Alfonso Quiñónez Molina]] (''acting'' 1918–1919, 1923–1927) * [[History of the Dominican Republic#The rise and fall of Trujillo 1924–65|Dominican Republic]]: [[Rafael Trujillo]] (''de facto'' 1930–1961, with brother [[Héctor Trujillo|Héctor]] serving as figurehead president 1952–1960), nominally succeeded by his son [[Ramfis Trujillo]] for a few months in 1961; Ramfis failed to fully consolidate his power over the country and was overthrown. * [[History of Nicaragua#Somoza Dynasty (1936–1979)|Nicaragua]]: [[Anastasio Somoza García]] ([[President of Nicaragua|President]], 1937–1947, ''de facto'' 1947–1950, 1950–1956), succeeded by his son [[Luis Somoza Debayle]] (1956–1963, ''de facto'' 1963–1967), succeeded by ''his'' brother [[Anastasio Somoza Debayle]] (1967–1972, ''de facto'' 1972–1974, 1974–1979). See also [[Somoza family]]. * [[Argentina]]: [[Juan Perón]] ([[President of Argentina|President]], 1946–55 and 1973–74); succeeded by his wife [[Isabel Martínez de Perón]] (1974–76). See also [[Peronism]]. * [[Haiti]]: [[François Duvalier]] ([[List of heads of state of Haiti|President]] and later [[President for life]], 1957–1971); succeeded by his son [[Jean-Claude Duvalier]] (President For Life, 1971–1986). See also [[Duvalier dynasty]]. * [[Cuba]]: [[Fidel Castro]] (1959–2008), succeeded by his brother [[Raúl Castro]] (2008–present).
===Asia=== [[File:Al Assad family.jpg|thumb|The [[Al-Assad family]] has ruled Syria since 1971.]] * [[North Korea]]: [[Kim Il-sung]] (1948–1994), succeeded by his son [[Kim Jong-il]] (1994–2011), succeeded by ''his'' son [[Kim Jong-un]] (2011–present). Kim Jong-il did not officially take office until 1997, when his father was posthumously given the position of [[Eternal President]]. On 2 June 2009, it was reported that Kim Jong-il's youngest son, [[Kim Jong-un]], was to be North Korea's next [[List of leaders of North Korea|leader]].<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jun/02/kim-jong-il-names-son-successor North Korean leader Kim Jong-il 'names youngest son as successor'], The Guardian, 2 June 2009</ref> Like his father and grandfather, he was given an official sobriquet, The Great Successor and The Brilliant Comrade.<ref>{{cite news |title=North Korea: A 'Brilliant Comrade' |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/13/world/asia/13briefs-NKOREAKIM.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=12 June 2009 |accessdate=13 June 2009 }}</ref> It was reported that Kim Jong-il was expected to officially designate the son as his successor in 2012,<ref name="news.yahoo.com">[https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090713/ap_on_re_as/as_nkorea_kim_jong_il;_ylt=ArJnECf9zWj56Y2i_pcr15sDW7oF "Report: NKorea's Kim has pancreatic cancer"], Associated Press, 12 July 2009.</ref> but Kim Jong-il [[Death and state funeral of Kim Jong-il|died in 2011]] and Kim Jong-un was nevertheless announced as his successor.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/20/world/asia/questions-about-north-koreas-stability-after-kim-jong-il.html?_r=1 |title=Kim’s Heir Likely to Focus on Stability |last=Fackler |first=Martin |date=2011-12-19 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=20 December 2011}}</ref> The 2013 edition of the "Ten Fundamental Principles of the [[Workers' Party of Korea|Korean Workers' Party]]" – Article 10, Clause 2 – states that the Party and Revolution must be carried "eternally" by the "Baekdu (Kim's) bloodline".<ref>[http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2013/08/13/2013081301558.html The Twisted Logic of the N. Korean Regime], Chosun Ilbo, 2013-08-13, Accessed date: 2017-01-11</ref> See also [[Kim dynasty (North Korea)|Kim Dynasty]]. * [[Iraqi Republic (1958–68)|Iraq]]: [[Abdul Salam Arif]] ([[List of Presidents of Iraq|President]], 1963–1966); succeeded by his brother [[Abdul Rahman Arif]] (1966–1968). * [[Syria]]: [[Hafez al-Assad]] (1971–2000), succeeded by his son [[Bashar al-Assad]] (2000–present). Bashar's elder brother, [[Basil al-Assad]], had been designated for the presidency but died in 1994, six years prior to his father's death. See also [[Al-Assad family]].
===Africa=== * [[Gabon]]: [[Omar Bongo]] ([[Omar Bongo#Pre-Presidency|Acting President]], 1966–1967; [[List of Presidents of Gabon|President]], 1967–2009) died in June 2009. His son [[Ali Bongo Ondimba]] (2009–present) succeeded him after winning a disputed election in August 2009. * [[Togo]]: [[Gnassingbé Eyadéma]] ([[List of heads of state of Togo|President]], 1967–2005); succeeded by his son [[Faure Gnassingbé]] (2005–present). Under international pressure, Faure had to resign on 25 February 2005, but was elected to the presidency in April 2005. * [[Djibouti]]: [[Hassan Gouled Aptidon]] ([[List of Presidents of Djibouti|President]], 1977–1999); succeeded by his nephew [[Ismaïl Omar Guelleh]] (1999–present). * [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]: [[Laurent-Désiré Kabila]] ([[List of heads of state of the Democratic Republic of the Congo|President]], 1997–2001); succeeded by his son [[Joseph Kabila]] (2001–present). Joseph Kabila was democratically elected in October 2006.
===Indirect successions=== * [[History of Taiwan since 1945|Republic of China]] (Taiwan): [[Chiang Kai-shek]] (1928–1975) indirectly succeeded by his son [[Chiang Ching-kuo]] (1978–1988) * [[Chechnya]]: [[Akhmad Kadyrov]] (2000–2004) indirectly succeeded by his son [[Ramzan Kadyrov]] (2007–present)<ref>Ramzan Kadyrov was First Deputy Prime Minister 2004–2005 and Prime Minister 2005–2007</ref> * [[Kabardino-Balkaria]]: [[Valery Kokov]] (1990–2005) indirectly succeeded by his son [[Kazbek Kokov]] (2018–present) * [[Singapore]]: [[Lee Kuan Yew]] (1959-1990) indirectly succeded by his son [[Lee Hsien Loong]] (2004-present)
==Unfulfilled successions== <!-- Please sort this list by the start of the first ruling period --> *[[China]]: After the death of [[Mao Zedong]] (1949–1976) his wife [[Jiang Qing]] planned a bloodless coup with the [[Gang of Four]]. It was rumored that Mao Zedong wanted his son [[Mao Anying]] to succeed him, but Mao Anying was [[killed in action]] during the [[Korean War]] in 1950. *[[South Vietnam]]: [[Ngô Đình Diệm]] ([[Leaders of South Vietnam#Prime Ministers|Prime Minister]], 1954–1955; [[President of the Republic of Vietnam|President]], 1955–1963) intended to hand power to his brother, [[Ngô Đình Nhu]] until both were [[Arrest and assassination of Ngo Dinh Diem|arrested and assassinated]] during the [[1963 South Vietnamese coup|1963 coup]]. *[[History of the Philippines (1965–86)|Philippines]]: [[Ferdinand Marcos]] (1965–1986) intended his wife [[Imelda Marcos|Imelda]] to be his successor but was ousted through the [[People Power Revolution]].<ref name = "The Steel Butterfly 2">[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/10/07/opinion/sunday/imelda-marcos-the-steel-butterfly-still-soars.html?_r=0 The Steel Butterfly Still Soars]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. October 6, 2012.</ref> *[[Socialist Republic of Romania|Romania]]: [[Elena Ceaușescu]], wife of Romanian dictator [[Nicolae Ceaușescu]] ([[List of heads of state of Romania|President of the State Council]], 1967–1989; [[List of Presidents of Romania|President]], 1974–1989), was intended to succeed her husband until they were [[Trial of Nicolae and Elena Ceaușescu|executed]] during the 1989 [[Romanian Revolution]].<ref>https://www.romania-insider.com/recently-declassified-c-documents-show-ceausescu-succession-scenarios-romanias-economic-situation/amp/</ref> Also, they were preparing their son, [[Nicu Ceausescu]] to succeed them. *[[History of Libya under Muammar Gaddafi|Libya]]: It was speculated that [[Saif al-Islam Gaddafi]], the second son of then-leader [[Muammar Gaddafi]] ([[Brotherly Leader and Guide of the Revolution]], 1969–2011) was going to succeed Gaddafi as leader, but Muammar was [[Libyan Civil War (2011)|overthrown]] and Saif al-Islam said that "this is not a farm to inherit".<ref name=IHT>[http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/08/22/mideast/libya.php "Qaddafi's son declares he's leaving politics"], Associated Press (''International Herald Tribune''), 22 August 2008.</ref> Muammar Gaddafi's fourth son [[Mutassim Gaddafi]] was considered Saif al-Islam's strongest competitor in the question of succeeding their father.<ref name="SZ">{{cite web|title=Süddeutsche Zeitung am 12. Oktober 2011: Verwirrung um Festnahme von Gaddafi-Sohn Mutassim|periodical=|publisher=|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/aufstaende-in-libyen-rebellen-nehmen-gaddafi-sohn-mutassim-fest-1.1161301|deadurl=|format=|accessdate=2011-11-01|archiveurl=|archivedate=|last=|date=|year=|month=|day=|language=|pages=|quote=}}</ref> *[[History of Bangladesh after independence|Bangladesh]]: Bangabandhu [[Sheikh Mujibur Rahman]] (1971–1975), the first [[List of Presidents of Bangladesh|President of Bangladesh]], expected his son [[Sheikh Kamal]] to succeed him. Both were [[Assassination of Sheikh Mujibur Rahman|assassinated in 1975]]. *[[Yemen]]: In 2004, [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]] ([[List of heads of state of Yemen#Yemen Arab Republic (1962–1990)|President of North Yemen]] then [[President of Yemen|President of unified Yemen]], 1978–2012) appointed his son, [[Ahmed Saleh]], as commander of the [[Republican Guard (Yemen)|Yemeni Republican Guard]] – a move interpreted by analysts as designating a family succession. Amid the [[Yemeni Revolution]] in 2012 and shortly after being elected president, [[Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi]] dissolved the Republican Guard, effectively removing Ahmed Saleh from any meaningful power. *[[Ba'athist Iraq|Iraq]]: [[Saddam Hussein]] (''de facto'' 1979–2003) designated his elder son [[Uday Hussein]] to succeed him as dictator, then changed the succession to his younger son [[Qusay Hussein]] after Uday suffered a severe injury in 1996. The U.S. invasion of Iraq and the death of both his sons, followed by Saddam's trial and subsequent execution made succession a moot point. See also [[Tulfah family#Saddam's family|Saddam's family]]. *[[Zimbabwe]]: [[Robert Mugabe]] ([[Prime Minister of Zimbabwe|Prime Minister]] then [[President of Zimbabwe|President]], 1980–2017) wanted his wife [[Grace Mugabe|Grace]] to succeed him,<ref>{{cite web|title= Mugabe - Vom Freiheitskämpfer zum Despoten |url=https://www.welt.de/newsticker/dpa_nt/afxline/topthemen/hintergruende/article170828032/Mugabe-Vom-Freiheitskaempfer-zum-Despoten.html|publisher=[[Welt (German TV channel)|Welt]] |date=November 21, 2017 |accessdate=2018-08-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Sie flog auf Staatskosten zum Shoppen nach New York|url=https://www.bild.de/politik/ausland/robert-gabriel-mugabe/und-seine-ehefrau-grace-53873974.bild.html|publisher=[[Bild]] |date=November 16, 2017 |accessdate=2018-08-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Das Volk hungert, die First Lady shoppt|url=https://www.tagesspiegel.de/politik/grace-mugabe-in-simbabwe-das-volk-hungert-die-first-lady-shoppt/20269934.html|publisher=[[Der Tagesspiegel]] |date=September 1, 2017 |accessdate=2018-08-04}}</ref> but this was prevented by a [[2017 Zimbabwean coup d'état|military coup]]. *[[Malaysia]]: [[Mahathir Mohamad]] ([[Prime Minister of Malaysia|Prime Minister]], 1981–2003; 2018–present) once told the [[High Courts (Malaysia)|high court]] that he would have made his son, [[Mukhriz Mahathir]], head of government long ago, but this never happened as Mahathir choose [[Anwar Ibrahim]] as his successor later.<ref>https://www.themalaysianinsight.com/s/40147</ref> *[[History of Egypt under Hosni Mubarak|Egypt]]: [[Hosni Mubarak]] ([[President of Egypt|President]], 1981–2011) groomed his son [[Gamal Mubarak]] to become his successor, but was ousted in the [[Egyptian revolution of 2011|2011 Egyptian revolution]].<ref>Aziz, Muhammad Abdul and Hussein, Youssef (2002) "The President, the Son, and the Military: Succession in Egypt" ''Arab Studies Journal'' 9/10: pp. 73–88</ref> *[[History of Venezuela (1999–present)|Venezuela]]: It was speculated that [[Adán Chávez]], the brother of then-leader [[Hugo Chávez]] ([[President of Venezuela|President]], 1999–2003) was going to succeed Chávez as president, but this never happened. There was also speculation that one of Hugo Chávez's daughters, Maria Gabriela or Rosa Virginia, would succeed him.<ref>https://foreignpolicy.com/2012/05/04/venezuela-the-succession/</ref> <!-- *[[Central African Republic]] father to son (Which one? Michel Djotodia, François Bozizé, Ange-Félix Patassé, or President/Emperor Jean-Bédel/Salah Eddine Ahmed Bokassa?) *[[Burkina Faso]]: It was rumored that [[Blaise Compaoré]] ([[President of Burkina Faso|President]], 1987–2014) was preparing to have his son succeed him. The [[2014 Burkinabé uprising]] and Compaoré fleeing to [[Ivory Coast]] made succession a moot point. -->
==Potential successions== * [[Azerbaijan]]: The [[Vice President of Azerbaijan|Vice President]] and [[First Lady of Azerbaijan|First Lady]] of Azerbaijan [[Mehriban Aliyeva]] is widely considered to be in line to succeed her husband [[Ilham Aliyev]] as [[President of Azerbaijan]]. Analysts also believe that their daughters [[Leyla Aliyeva|Leyla]] and [[Arzu Aliyeva|Arzu]] are also being prepared as their father's or their mother's successors.<ref> Haley Sweetland Edwards, [http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2010/12/azerbaijan-wikileaks-depicts-lifestyles-of-bakus-rich-and-powerful.html “AZERBAIJAN: WikiLeaks depicts lifestyles of Baku's rich and powerful”], ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', 25 Dec 2010, Accessed 26 Mar 2013 </ref> On 21 February 2017 Mehriban Aliyeva was appointed [[Vice President of Azerbaijan]], an office that was created through a [[Azerbaijani constitutional referendum, 2016|constitutional referendum in 2016]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://en.apa.az/azerbaijan-politics/domestic-news/mehriban-aliyeva-appointed-first-vice-president-of-azerbaijan.html|title=Mehriban Aliyeva appointed first vice-president of Azerbaijan|last=Holding|first=APA Information Agency, APA|date=2017-02-21|access-date=2017-02-21|language=en}}</ref> * [[Belarus]]: It is rumored that [[President of Belarus|President]] [[Alexander Lukashenko]] has been preparing to have his young son [[Nikolai Lukashenko|Nikolai]] succeed him.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/belarus/11925324/Alexander-Lukashenko-The-leader-who-wants-to-turn-Belarus-into-a-North-Korean-style-dynasty.html|title=Meet the pint-sized dictator: The 11-year-old heir groomed in North Korea-style dynasty for Belarus|last=Oliphant|first=Roland|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=11 October 2015|access-date=31 July 2017}}</ref> Observers have noted how Lukashenko often brings his son on official engagements.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34411326|title=Why does Belarus President Lukashenko take son Kolya to work?|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=1 October 2015|access-date=31 July 2017}}</ref> On some occasions Nikolai is given a chair with the other heads of state, in sharp contrast with, for instance, the children of the then-President of Uzbekistan [[Islam Karimov]] also present in the conference room. * [[Cambodia]]: The [[List of Prime Ministers of Cambodia|Cambodian prime minister]], [[Hun Sen]], has appointed his eldest son, [[Hun Manet]], to a higher military command to prepare him for the premiership.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/cambodian-strongmans-son-assumes-powerful-military-roles |title=Cambodian strongman's son assumes powerful military role|publisher=[[The Straits Times]] |date=June 30, 2018 |accessdate=2018-07-11 | location=Phnom Penh}}</ref> * [[Equatorial Guinea]]: On 3 August 1979, [[President of Equatorial Guinea|President]] [[Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo]] seized power from his uncle<ref>{{cite news |title=After the Mugabes, which African dynasties remain? |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-42009211 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=19 November 2017 |access-date=19 November 2017}}</ref> [[Francisco Macías Nguema]]. It is rumored that his son, the [[Vice President of Equatorial Guinea|First Vice President]] [[Teodoro Nguema Obiang Mangue]], is his favorite to succeed him<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/article626511.ece |title=Playboy waits for his African throne |publisher=[[Times Online]] |date=September 3, 2006 |accessdate=2010-05-05 | location=London, Cape Town | first1=RW | last1=Johnson}}</ref> (see also [[Equatorial Guinean constitutional referendum, 2011]]). However, it is suspected that a power struggle between the younger Teodoro and his uncle [[Armengol Ondo Nguema]] might occur after President Obiang's death. * [[Kazakhstan]]: Analysts believe long-time [[President of Kazakhstan|president]] [[Nursultan Nazarbayev]] has been preparing his daughter [[Dariga Nazarbayeva]] to succeed him. Despite a strained relationship during 2013;<ref>[http://www.rferl.org/featuresarticle/2006/05/C68B3EB0-8C9F-4AE1-9B39-344A33610EA7.html Kazakhstan: Apparent Rift Opens Within Nazarbaev Family]. [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]].</ref> in September 2016, Dariga was appointed to the [[Senate of Kazakhstan|Senate]] – she was designated as head of the Senate's International Affairs, Defense, and Security Committee.<ref>[http://www.rferl.org/a/kazakhstan-nazarbaeva-appointed-senate-committee-chairs/27992983.html "Kazakh president's daughter appointed head of Senate committee"], Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, 16 September 2016.</ref> * [[Nicaragua]]: On 10 January 2017, [[Rosario Murillo]], wife of [[President of Nicaragua|Nicaraguan president]] [[Daniel Ortega]], was appointed as [[Vice President of Nicaragua|vice president of Nicaragua]], which raised speculation that Murillo will succeed Ortega as president later.<ref>{{cite news |title=Rosario Murillo Has Two Options to Follow Ortega in Nicaragua as President |url=https://confidencial.com.ni/rosario-murillo-two-options-to-follow-ortega-in-nicaragua-as-president/ |publisher=confidencial.com.ni |date=July 28, 2016 |access-date=July 11, 2018}}</ref> * [[Philippines]]: On 22 September 2017, [[Rodrigo Duterte]] said of his daughter [[Sara Duterte|Sara]] that "I couldn’t find any other better candidate than Sara to become the next president",<ref>{{cite news |title=Sara for President? Duterte just trusts daughter, not trying to hold on to power, says Palace|url=https://www.gmanetwork.com/news/news/nation/627144/sara-for-president-duterte-just-trusts-daughter-not-trying-to-hold-on-to-power-says-palace/story/|publisher=[[GMA Network]]|date=September 25, 2017|access-date=August 4, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Rody eyes daughter Sara as successor|url=https://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/09/23/1742137/rody-eyes-daughter-sara-successor|publisher=[[The Philippine Star]]|date=September 23, 2017|access-date=August 4, 2018}}</ref> he later claimed he was joking.<ref>{{cite news |title=Duterte says remark about daughter as his successor a 'joke'|url=https://www.sunstar.com.ph/article/166886/Duterte-says-remark-about-daughter-as-his-successor-a-joke|publisher=[[Sun.Star]]|date=September 30, 2017|access-date=August 4, 2018}}</ref> * [[Russia]]: There's a rumor that [[President of Russia|Russian President]] [[Vladimir Putin]] is preparing his daughter, [[Katerina Tikhonova]], to run in the [[Russian presidential election, 2024|2024 presidential election]], as he's unlikely to run for a fifth term due to his age.<ref>https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/4782015/vladimir-putin-russia-daughter-katerina-leader-kremlin-dynasty/</ref> * [[Singapore]]: Critics believe that [[Lee Hsien Loong]] is preparing one of his sons, [[Li Hongyi (Singaporean officer)|Li Hongyi]], to succeed him. * [[Tajikistan]]: On 3 April 2017, [[Rustam Emomali]], the son of [[President of Tajikistan|President]] [[Emomali Rahmon]], was elected to the city legislature of the capital and largest city, [[Dushanbe]]. This made Rahmon's earlier appointment of Rustam Emomali as [[Mayor]] of Dushanbe legal. President Rahmon has other "close relatives" in "high official positions" in Tajikistan.<ref>{{cite news |title=Tajik President's Son Cements Mayoral Post With Election To Dushanbe Legislature |url=http://www.rferl.org/a/tajikistan-emomali-cements-dushanbe-mayor-post/28407746.html |publisher=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty's Tajik Service |date=April 3, 2017 |access-date=April 4, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Daughter Of Tajik President Named Deputy Head Of Major Bank |url=https://www.rferl.org/a/tajikista-rahmon-daughter-zarina-bank/28624368.html |publisher=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty's Tajik Service |date=July 18, 2017 |access-date=August 1, 2017}}</ref> For example, [[Ozoda Rahmon]], one of President Rahmon's daughters, is both her father's chief of the presidential staff and a member of the [[Supreme Assembly (Tajikistan)|National Assembly]], the upper house of the Tajik parliament.<ref>{{cite news |title=Daughter Of Tajikistan's President Elected To Upper Chamber Of Parliament |url=https://www.rferl.org/a/tajikistan-rahmon-parliament/27764317.html |publisher=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty's Tajik Service |date=May 29, 2016 |access-date=August 1, 2017}}</ref> * [[Turkey]]: Some observers believe that especially since the shock of the [[2016 Turkish coup d'état attempt|2016 coup attempt]], President [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan|Erdogan]] tends to trust his own family more than his [[Justice and Development Party (Turkey)|party]] or senior bureaucrats.<ref>{{cite news |title=Die Nachfolge Erdogans: alles bleibt in der Familie|url=https://www.stuttgarter-nachrichten.de/inhalt.der-tuerkische-praesident-baut-seinen-nachfolger-auf-die-nachfolge-erdogans-alles-bleibt-in-der-familie.fff22b55-5212-4c0f-8f49-a08e9379abc0.html|publisher=[[Stuttgarter Nachrichten]]|date=July 18, 2018 |access-date=August 4, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Erdogans Macht soll in der Familie bleiben|url=https://www.saarbruecker-zeitung.de/erdogans-macht-soll-in-der-familie-bleiben_aid-23986841|publisher=[[Saarbrücker Zeitung]]|date=July 18, 2018 |access-date=August 4, 2018}}</ref> A potential successor could be his son-in-law [[Berat Albayrak]], who holds the influential post of [[Ministry of Finance (Turkey)|finance minister]] and a seat on the [[Supreme Military Council (Turkey)|Supreme Military Council]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Bei den Erdogans bleibt alles in der Familie|url=https://rp-online.de/politik/ausland/recep-tayyip-erdogan-baut-seinen-schwiegersohn-zum-nachfolger-auf_aid-24042023|publisher=[[Rheinische Post]]|date=July 23, 2018|access-date=August 4, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Wie Erdogan seinen Schwiegersohn Albayrak zum Nachfolger aufbaut|url=https://www.tagesspiegel.de/politik/tuerkei-wie-erdogan-seinen-schwiegersohn-albayrak-zum-nachfolger-aufbaut/22831074.html|publisher=[[Der Tagesspiegel]]|date=July 22, 2018|access-date=August 4, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Zoff um Erdogan-Nachfolge? Die Türkei diskutiert über diesen Rempler|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.de/entry/zoff-um-erdogan-nachfolge-die-turkei-diskutiert-uber-diesen-rempler_de_5b6540a6e4b0de86f4a1a0e7|publisher=[[HuffPost]]|date=August 4, 2018|access-date=August 4, 2018}}</ref> * [[Turkmenistan]]: On 22 March 2017, the son of [[President of Turkmenistan|President]] [[Gurbanguly Berdimuhamedow]], [[Assembly of Turkmenistan|Assembly member]] Sardar Berdimuhamedow, was appointed to chair the parliament's legal affairs committee – a move interpreted to be bringing Sardar closer to succeeding Gurbanguly.<ref>{{cite news |title=Turkmen President's Son Becomes Senior Lawmaker In Parliament |url=http://www.rferl.org/a/turkmenistan-parliament-berdymukhammedov-son/28382915.html |publisher=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty |date=March 21, 2017 |access-date=March 22, 2017}}</ref> * [[Uganda]]: Critics believe long-time president [[Yoweri Museveni]] has been preparing his son [[Muhoozi Kainerugaba]] to succeed him. The President's son was commander of Uganda's military elite Special Forces Group until January 2017 when the President appointed him Senior Adviser to the President for Special Operations, plus since 1998 Muhoozi has gone from the rank of Major to Major-General in quick succession. All of this is leading the succession rumours to swell even more.{{citation needed|date=May 2018}} *[[Venezuela]]: There is a rumor that [[Nicolás Maduro Guerra]], the son of Venezuelan leader [[Nicolás Maduro]], is being prepared to succeed his father as Maduro Guerra was named in 2017 as the director of a newly established position, the Director General of Delegations and Presidential Instructions of the Vice President.<ref>{{cite news|title=El hijo de Nicolás Maduro se prepara para ser el sucesor de la revolución chavistar|url=https://www.lainformacion.com/mundo/el-hijo-de-nicolas-maduro-se-prepara-para-ser-el-sucesor-de-la-revolucion-chavista_tXVo09fxNS4kOHLUfZHTu7/|publisher=La Información|access-date=August 4, 2018}}</ref> <!--* [[Cameroon]] father to son-->

{{lead too short|date=October 2016}} [[File:Flag_of_Hejaz_1917.svg|thumb|[[File:FIAV 110110.svg|23px]] Flag ratio: 2:3]] [[Image:CCL5 072.jpg|thumb|The flag of the Arab revolt- Aqaba 2006]] The '''Flag of the Arab Revolt''' also known as the [[Kingdom of Hejaz|Flag of Hejaz]] was a [[flag]] used by the [[Arab nationalists]] during the [[Arab Revolt]] against the [[Ottoman Empire]] during [[World War I]].
==History== [[File:030Arab.jpg|thumb|left|Soldiers in the Arab Army during the Arab Revolt of 1916–1918. They are carrying the flag of the Arab Revolt and are pictured in the Arabian Desert.]]
The flag was designed by the [[United Kingdom|British]] diplomat Sir [[Mark Sykes]], in an effort to create a feeling of "Arab-ness" in order to fuel the revolt.<ref>William Easterly, ''The White Man's Burden'' (2006), p. 295</ref> Although the Arab Revolt was only very limited in scope and concerted by the British rather than by Arabs themselves, the flag influenced the [[national flags]] of a number of emerging [[Arab World|Arab states]] after World War I. Flags inspired by that of the Arab revolt include those of [[Flag of Egypt|Egypt]], [[Flag of Jordan|Jordan]], [[Flag of Iraq|Iraq]], [[Flag of Kuwait|Kuwait]], [[Flag of Sudan|Sudan]], [[Flag of Syria|Syria]], the [[Flag of the United Arab Emirates|United Arab Emirates]], [[Flag of Yemen|Yemen]], [[Palestinian flag|Palestine]], [[Flag of Somaliland|Somaliland]], the [[Flag of Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic|Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic]] and [[Flag of Libya|Libya]].
The horizontal colors stand for the [[Abbasid]] (black), [[Umayyad]] (white) and [[Fatimid]] (green) [[Caliphates]]. The red triangle refers to the [[Hashemite]] dynasty.<ref>Edmund Midura, [https://www.saudiaramcoworld.com/issue/197802/flags.of.the.arab.world.htm "Flags of the Arab World"], in ''Saudi Aramco World'', March/April 1978, pages 4–9</ref><ref>Mahdi Abdul-Hadi, [http://www.passia.org/palestine_facts/meaning_of_flag.htm "Palestine Facts: The Meaning of the Flag"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131222200644/http://www.passia.org/palestine_facts/meaning_of_flag.htm |date=2013-12-22}}</ref> Alternately, the colours' symbolism has been described as follows: white for the Damascene [[Umayyad]] period, green for the [[Caliph Ali]], red for the [[Khawarij]] radical Islamic movement, and black for the [[Prophet Mohammed]], showing the "political use of religion" in opposition to the increasingly secularized Turkish colonial rule.<ref>Sergie, Lina, ''[https://dspace.mit.edu/handle/1721.1/70372 Recollecting history : songs, flags and a Syrian square]'' Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Dept. of Architecture, 2003</ref>
The Hashemites were allies of the British in the conflict against the Ottoman Empire. After the war ended, the Hashemites achieved or were granted rule in the [[Hejaz]] region of [[Arabia]], [[Jordan]], formally known as the ''Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan'', briefly in [[Arab Kingdom of Syria|Greater Syria]], and [[Iraq]].
Greater Syria was dissolved after only a few months of existence, in 1920. The Hashemites were overthrown in the Hejaz in 1925 by the [[House of Saud]], and in Iraq in 1958 by a [[coup d'etat]], but retained power in [[Jordan]].
A 60 m × 30 m version of the flag currently flies from the [[Aqaba Flagpole]], currently the sixth tallest freestanding [[flagpole]] in the world, located in [[Aqaba]], [[Jordan]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.andrewcusack.com/2016/arab-revolt-flag/ |title=The Flag of the Arab Revolt |publisher=andrewcusack.com |access-date=2016-10-20}}</ref>
==Description== The [[flag]] contains the four [[Pan-Arab colors]]: [[black]], [[white]], [[green]] and [[red]]. There are three horizontal stripes: black, green, and white, going down the flag. There is also a red triangle on the hoist side of the flag.

{{also|Khomenko}} '''Fomenko''' is a ([[Cyrillic]]: Фоменко) is a Russified form of a Ukrainian surname derived from the name Thomas ({{lang-ru|Фома}}, Foma). The Ukrainian form of the surname is Khomenko.
It may refer to:
*[[Anatoly Fomenko]], Russian mathematician and topologist, known for his work on historical revisionism *[[Mykhailo Fomenko]], Ukrainian football coach and former player *[[Nikolai Fomenko]], Russian rock musician and motor racer *[[Pavel Fomenko]], Russian high jumper *[[Serhiy Fomenko]], Ukrainian singer *[[Yuliya Fomenko (swimmer)|Yuliya Fomenko]], Russian backstroke swimmer *[[Arturas Fomenko]], football player {{surname}}<!-- It does not help to add disambig or hndis tags where the page only contains people who share a surname --> [[Category:Ukrainian-language surnames]] [[Category:Russification]]

Partnership|access-date=2018-08-01|language=en-US}}</ref> and is a think-tank on global [[Water resource management|water governance]] and its challenges<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.eip-water.eu/geneva-water-hub|title=Geneva Water Hub {{!}} EIP Water|website=www.eip-water.eu|language=en|access-date=2018-10-10}}</ref>.
== History and Key Work== Founded in 2014, the Geneva Water Hub, with offices at the [[University of Geneva]] and the [[World Meteorological Organization]], works to bridge the gap between water research, policy and practice on the ground - often at cross boundary and [[River Basin|river basin]] scale.
From 2015 until 2017 it acted as the Secretariat to the [[Global High-Level Panel on Water and Peace|Global High Level Panel on Water and Peace]] and now acts as the secretariat for the Group of Friends for Water and Peace<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.genevawaterhub.org/platforms/group-friends-water-and-peace|title=Group of Friends on Water and Peace {{!}} Geneva Water Hub|website=www.genevawaterhub.org|language=en|access-date=2018-11-19}}</ref>, about forty countries represented by their Permanent Missions to the United Nations in Geneva<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.admin.ch/gov/en/start/dokumentation/medienmitteilungen.msg-id-63865.html|title=“Transforming water into a source of cooperation and peace”|last=Council|first=The Federal|website=www.admin.ch|language=en|access-date=2018-08-01}}</ref>. It also coordinates the Universities Partnership for Water Cooperation and Diplomacy, launched at the 2018 [[World Economic Forum]] in [[Davos|Davos, Switzerland]] with IHE Delft Institute for Water Education<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.un-ihe.org/|title=Home {{!}} IHE Delft Institute for Water Education|website=www.un-ihe.org|language=en|access-date=2018-08-01}}</ref>, the Indian Institute of Technology Guwahati<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.iitg.ac.in/|title=Indian Institute of Technology Guwahati|website=www.iitg.ac.in|access-date=2018-08-01}}</ref>, the German-Kazakh University in Almaty<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.geo.fu-berlin.de/en/v/iwm-network/partners/Kazakh-German_University/index.html|title=Kazakh-German University|date=2013-08-30|website=www.geo.fu-berlin.de|language=en|access-date=2018-08-01}}</ref>, and Oregon State University<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gradwater.oregonstate.edu/|title=Water Resources Graduate Program|website=Water Resources Graduate Program|language=en|access-date=2018-08-01}}</ref>. This university consortium was established to encourage dialogue and capacity-building between countries and among different professional sectors.
=== Water and Peace === In 2015, the World Economic Forum ranked [[water scarcity]] as the largest global risk over the next decade<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2015/01/why-world-water-crises-are-a-top-global-risk/|title=Water crises are a top global risk|website=World Economic Forum|access-date=2018-08-01}}</ref>. Already, 40% of the world's population is affected by water scarcity<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sustainabledevelopment.un.org/content/documents/17825HLPW_Outcome.pdf|title=Making Every Drop Count|last=Water|first=High Level Panel on|date=14 March 2018|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-01}}</ref> on a planet where more than 260 international rivers cross many man-made boundaries. In addition, more than half the planet's [[Wetland|wetlands]] have disappeared<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://wwf.panda.org/?322330/Half-of-the-worlds-wetlands-have-disappeared-since-1900|title=Half of the world's wetlands have disappeared since 1900!|access-date=2018-08-01|language=en}}</ref> and [[climate change]] is impacting weather and water patterns around the world.
Yet, as the dialogue of ‘water wars’ increases, research shows that water is far more a tool for cooperation and peace than conflict. During the 20<sup>th</sup> century there were only seven minor confrontations over water, with 145 treaties signed in the same 100 years.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wolf|first=Aaron T.|date=2007-11-01|title=Shared Waters: Conflict and Cooperation|url=https://www.annualreviews.org/doi/abs/10.1146/annurev.energy.32.041006.101434|journal=Annual Review of Environment and Resources|language=en|volume=32|issue=1|pages=241–269|doi=10.1146/annurev.energy.32.041006.101434|issn=1543-5938|via=}}</ref>
Through academic research, policy and hydro-diplomacy the Geneva Water Hub works to shift the global dialogue from ‘[[Water conflict|water and conflict]]’ to ‘water for peace and cooperation’, to deliver better water governance and the long-term protection of critical water resources and infrastructure.
=== Global High-Level Panel on Water and Peace === In 2015, the Geneva Water Hub began working as Secretariat to the [[Global High-Level Panel on Water and Peace|Global High Level Panel on Water and Peace]] – a 15 country co-convened initiative focused on strengthening the global framework to prevent and resolve water-related conflicts and to facilitate the use of water as an instrument of peace and cooperation<ref name="auto1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.unwater.org/report-global-high-level-panel-water-peace/|title=Report of the Global High Level Panel on Water and Peace {{!}} UN-Water|date=2017-09-18|work=UN-Water|access-date=2018-08-01|language=en-US}}</ref>.
In its 2017 report “A Matter of Survival”<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://reliefweb.int/report/world/matter-survival-report-global-high-level-panel-water-and-peace|title=A Matter of Survival - Report of the Global High-Level Panel on Water and Peace - World|work=ReliefWeb|access-date=2018-10-10|language=en}}</ref> the Global High-Level Panel on Water and Peace outlined its recommendations for a fundamental rethinking of international water cooperation from the [[United Nations Security Council|UN Security Council]] to other multilateral institutions and down to grass-roots level organisations.
=== Water Governance Education === At the University of Geneva, the Geneva Water Hub runs an annual Summer School in Water Governance and a distance learning course on International Water Law and the Law of Transboundary Aquifers. It also offers several open access [[Massive open online course|Massive Online Open Courses]] for water technicians and the water policy community on topics such as water resources policy and management, international water law and [[ecosystem services]].

{{Infobox film |name = Hammer & Tickle |image = Hammer_&_Tickle_poster.jpg |caption = Theatrical release poster |director = [[Ben Lewis (filmmaker)|Ben Lewis]]{{cite web|title=Hammer & Tickle film information|url=http://www.thempi.org/mpi_films/hammerandtickle.html|publisher=[[Moving Picture Institute]]|accessdate=30 May 2014}} |producer = Christine Camdessus,
Leah Mallen |writer = Ben Lewis |narrator = Ben Lewis |starring = |music = |cinematography = |editing = Jules Cornell |distributor = |released = |runtime = 89 min. |country = United States |language = English |budget = |gross = }} '''''Hammer & Tickle: The Communist Joke Book''''' is a 2006 [[documentary film]] about the nature of [[Russian political joke]]s under the powerful and socially restrictive [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Communist regime]] of the [[Soviet Union]] and its [[Satellite state#Soviet satellite states|satellite nations]]. The film's name exemplifies the kind of mockery or criticism of the regime that the Soviet government would have found to be disagreeable by playing on the [[Communist symbolism|symbol of communism]] itself, the [[hammer and sickle]]. The film tells the story of the power that jokes had to enable social and political change and advance personal freedoms from within the USSR - the film's opening scene uses a quote from [[George Orwell]]'s ''[[Nineteen Eighty-Four|1984]]'': "Every joke is a tiny revolution." ==Content== Under the [[Chronology of Soviet secret police agencies|watchful eyes]] of the oppressive Soviet government, the Russian people had very few outlets in which they could publicly express their disapproval of their government and its policies. The film shows the story of how jokes served as an outlet for the people's expression of their desire for reform and freedom. These jokes were often told quietly to one another, as to avoid retribution from the Soviet [[secret police]] agencies who kept a close eye on such expressions of [[Civil disobedience|political dissent]]. Oftentimes, however, even private and seemingly benign displays of such dissent couldn't escape detection. Eva Kovacs of the Secret Police Archives in Hungary tells the story of a university student who spent two years in prison and had all his possessions confiscated after telling an unseemly joke about [[Mátyás Rákosi|Comrade Rákosi]]. In an interview with Ilie Merce ([[:ro:Ilie Merce|ro]]), former Colonel of the [[Communist Romania]]n secret police agency [[Securitate]], Merce says that his agency paid particular attention to jokes about the lack of availability of basic products and the censorship of television, as they "functioned as indicators of the spirit of the people." On several occasions, the film shows [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Ronald Reagan]] poking fun at the Soviet Union's shortcomings, highlighting how he too used humor to sway public opinion. ==Reception== ''Hammer & Tickle'' premiered at the [[Tribeca Film Festival]] in 2006 to positive reviews,{{cite web|last=Fischer|first=Martha|title=Tribeca Review: Hammer & Tickle -- The Communist Joke Book|url=http://blog.moviefone.com/2006/04/10/tribeca-review-hammer-and-tickle-the-communist-joke-book/|accessdate=28 November 2011|publisher=[[Moviefone]]|date=10 April 2006}} and won the title of "Best Documentary" at the [[Zurich Film Festival]] later that year.{{cite web|url=http://www.hammerandtickle.com/?cat=3|title=Ben Lewis Biography|year=2011|work=Hammer and Tickle|accessdate=30 May 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120318055521/http://www.hammerandtickle.com/?cat=3|archivedate=2012-03-18}} Lewis published an essay (in ''[[Prospect Magazine]]'', 2006)[http://www.prospectmagazine.co.uk/magazine/communist-jokes/#.U4hGSyjwuSo "Hammer & tickle"], ''[[Prospect (magazine)|Prospect Magazine]]'', May 2006, essay by [[Ben Lewis (filmmaker)|Ben Lewis]] and book ([[Weidenfeld & Nicolson]], 2008)Ben Lewis (2008) "Hammer and Tickle", {{ISBN|0-297-85354-6}} ([http://www.economist.com/books/displayStory.cfm?source=hptextfeature&story_id=11662223 a review online]) with the same title. == See also == * [[Russian political jokes]] * [[Soviet phraseology]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.benlewis.tv/category/films/films_hat/ Hammer & Tickle] at benlewis.tv *{{IMDb title|0870117}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hammer and Tickle}} [[Category:2000s documentary films]] [[Category:2006 films]] [[Category:Communism]] [[Category:American political satire films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Russian humour]]

{{Infobox person |name = Hans Martin Sutermeister |image =Hans Martin Sutermeister at home, aug. 1961.JPG |caption = Hans Martin Sutermeister in 1961 |birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1907|9|29}} |birth_place = [[Schlossrued]], [[Switzerland]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1977|5|4|1907|9|29}} |death_place = [[Basel]], Switzerland |spouse = |residence = Switzerland |citizenship = Swiss |alma_mater = [[University of Basel]] |known_for = activism against [[Miscarriage of justice|miscarriages of justice]] |signature = Autograph of Hans Martin Sutermeister.svg |footnotes = }} '''Hans Martin Sutermeister''' (29 September 1907 – 4 May 1977 pen name: Hans Moehrlen) was a [[Swiss]] [[physician]] and [[medical writer]], [[politician]], and activist against [[Miscarriage of justice|miscarriages of justice]]. ==Life== ===Early years=== Hans Martin was born to Freidrich Sutermeister (1873-1934) and Maria Hunziker (1875-1947). His brothers include the writer [[Peter Sutermeister|Peter]] and composer [[Heinrich Sutermeister|Heinrich]]. His grandfather was the folklorist [[Otto Sutermeister]]. A minister's son, Hans Martin studied [[theology]] in Germany, changing to medicine at [[University of Basel]] just before completing his degree.Gerhard Mauz. [http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-46272426.html “Schuldig, weil wir keinen anderen haben: SPIEGEL-Reporter Gerhard Mauz über die Fehlurteilsjäger Hans Martin Sutermeister und Gustav Adolf Neumann.”] In: ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' 18/28, April 1965, p. 116 (German). After his [[Doctorate|promotion]] with his uncle [[Hans Hunziker]] in 1941, Sutermeister published, under the pseudonym “Hans Moehrlen” (following the surname of his great-grandfather [[Christophe Moehrlen]]), an autobiographical novella about his life as a [[bachelor]]. The novella describes his philosophical change of direction towards a [[monism|monist]] view of love and happiness, inspired by natural science; remarkably is its heartedness in times of [[World War II|war]].{{Citation |publisher = Buchdruckerei Mettler & Salz A.G. |publication-place = Bern, Switzerland |title = Zwischen zwei Welten |url = http://openlibrary.org/books/OL24635691M/Zwischen_zwei_Welten |author = Hans Moehrlen (Pseudonym) |publication-date = 1942 |oclc = 72283656 |isbn = 978-3-226-00030-6 }} In the following years, Sutermeister published a series on [[neopositivism|neopositivist]] medical thought. He was especially interested in [[psychosomatic]] medicine and [[music psychology]]. For example, according to him, “[[swing music]] is restful” because
the brain becomes fatigued when it is worked too hard, as in acquiring knowledge of new facts. Both students and business men can benefit by such music … the best way to rest the brain after such fatigue is to “[[Regression (psychology)|regress]]” to more basic or primitive forms of thought and feeling.[https://books.google.com/books?id=efUDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA99&lpg=PA99&dq=%22Dr.+H+M+Sutermeister%22&source=bl&ots=NgZNnKKMrS&sig=CZX48jDsCLA85cDWrtf2CTnK3wA&hl=pt-BR&ei=tNzBTKzPE8KaOtT9yMoL&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBYQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Dr.%20H%20M%20Sutermeister%22&f=false “Swiss Says Swing Smoothly Soothes.”] In: ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'', January 17, 1948.
During [[World War II]], he worked for the [[United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration]] in Germany, [[Poland]] and [[Czechoslovakia]], as well as a physician at the Swiss border. After the war he wrote for medical journals and was an instructor in [[psychophysiology]] at the [[Volkshochschule]] (Folk high school) in [[Bern]]. In 1945, he opened his first a [[family medicine|family medical]] practice in Bern.{{Citation needed|date=November 2009}} In order to get a [[venia legendi]] in [[History of Medicine]] and [[Medical Psychology]] (Psychosomatics), Sutermeister successively deposited, at the beginning of the 1950s, three [[Habilitation|post-doctoral theses]] at the Medical Faculty of the [[University of Berne]]:[https://archive.org/details/JakobKlaesiToBernhardWalthard6.9.1954 ''Betrifft Habilitationsgesuch des Dr. med. H. M. Sutermeister'']. Letter from [[Jakob Klaesi]] to [[Bernhard Walthard]], September 6, 1954. * ''About the changes in the perception of the disease'';{{cite journal| last =Sutermeister | first =Hans Martin | title =Über die Wandlungen in der Auffassung des Krankheitsgeschehens | journal =[[International Journal of Public Health|Gesundheit und Wohlfahrt]] | volume =27 | issue =12 | pages =417–460 | publisher = | location = | year =1947 | language = | url = | issn = }} * ''Psychosomatics of laughter and crying'' (a philosophical-psychological and physiological work on the [[Humor in Freud|Freud's theory of humor]]);{{cite journal| last =Sutermeister | first =Hans Martin | title =Psychosomatik des Lachens und Weinens | journal =Gesundheit und Wohlfahrt | volume =32 | issue =6 | pages =337–371 | publisher = | location = | year =1952 | language = | url = | issn = }} * ''Schiller as physician: a contribution to psychosomatic medicine.{{cite journal| last =Sutermeister | first =Hans Martin | title =Schiller als Arzt: ein Beitrag zur Geschichte der psychosomatischen Forschung | journal =Berner Beiträge zur Geschichte der Medizin und der Naturwissenschaften | volume = | issue =13 | pages = | publisher =Paul Haupt | location =Bern | year =1955 | language = | url = | issn = }} Sutermeister was in contact with the medical historian [[Erich Hintzsche]] particularly because of his work ''Schiller as physician'', and he participated in a seminar on medical history 1953 in Lugano. In a letter to Hintzsche, [[Henry E. Sigerist]] described Sutermeister's review, published in 1955 as Volume 13 of the ''Berne contributions to the history of medicine and natural sciences'', as “a very nice work … that is interesting even to [[literary historian]]s.”[[Marcel H. Bickel]]: ''[[Henry E. Sigerist]]: Vier ausgewählte Briefwechsel mit Medizinhistorikern der Schweiz.'' (Correspondence with [[Arnold C. Klebs]], [[Bernhard Milt]], [[Hans Fischer (medical historian)|Hans Fischer]] and [[Erich Hintzsche]].) [[Peter Lang (publishing company)|Peter Lang]], Bern 2008. Pages 378 and 572–574. {{ISBN|978-3-03911-499-3}} The assessor [[Jakob Klaesi]] recommended to the Dean of the Faculty [[Bernhard Walthard]] to allow Sutermeister's habilitation allow for the government to issue Sutermeister's habilitation as a lecturer in Medicine history and Psychosomatic medicine. Hintzsche, however, who decided jointly, rejected his habilitation. ===Politics=== [[File:Nico cartoon 1971.jpg|thumb|cartoon by [[Klaus Peter Cadsky|Nico]] on Sutermeister's deselection as Bernese city counciller after the [[The Little Red Schoolbook#Reception|schoolbook]] affair, 1971.]] He joined the [[Ring of Independents]] political party and began his political career in the [[Grand Council of Bern|legislature of the Canton of Bern]]. From 1967 to 1971 he served as a member of the municipal [[Executive (government)|executive]], as well as director of the city's schools.{{cite book |last=Bähler |first=Anna |author2=Bühler, Susanna |author3=Erne, Emil |author4=Lüthi, Christian |editor=Barth, Robert |title=Bern - die Geschichte der Stadt im 19. und 20. Jahrhundert: Stadtentwicklung, Gesellschaft, Wirtschaft, Politik, Kultur |url=http://www.stub.unibe.ch/extern/hv/be19_20/index.html |accessdate=2008-07-10 |edition=2nd |year=2003 |publisher=Stämpfli Verlag AG |location=Berne |language=german |isbn=3-7272-1271-3 |pages=153 |chapter=3:Stadtpolitik zwischen Patriziat und Frauenmehrheit |chapterurl=http://bme10a.arrocho.ch/downloads/bernim19und20jhpolitikimwandel2.pdf |ref=Bern2003 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070909052323/http://www.stub.unibe.ch/extern/hv/be19_20/index.html |archive-date=2007-09-09 |dead-url=yes |df= }} As school director, he promoted [[comprehensive school]]s. Although he had a reputation as a progressive within his party, he also stirred some concern both inside and outside the party[http://www.anneepolitique.ch/APS/fr/APS_1971/APS1971_I_1_e.html Élections communales, année politique Suisse 1971], University of Bern (French - password required): ''A Berne, lors des élections à l'exécutif communal, les radicaux, grâce à A. Rollier, purent reprendre aux indépendants le siège qu'ils avaient dû céder de justesse à H. Sutermeister, personnalité souvent contestée durant l'exercice de son mandat''. by fiercely criticizing ''[[The Little Red Schoolbook]]'',Klaus H. Thiele-Dohrmann, [http://www.zeit.de/1970/30/Ruhestoerung-in-Bern?page=all “Ruhestörung in Bern.”]{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ''[[Die Zeit]]'' July 24, 1970 (German): ''in einem kleinen Privatkrieg heftig attackiert''. an educational manifesto deriving from the [[Protests of 1968|1968 student protest movement]] that urged students to reject societal norms. ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' quoted his warning to all educators:
We will not permit our youth, who are today still healthy, and our freedom-based Western culture, to be undermined by such softening-up tactics, which are clearly controlled from the East, and made 'Ready for conquest' by Communism.[http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-44943670.html “Der SPIEGEL berichtete: Schüler-Lehrerbeziehung.”] ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' 28/1970, July 6, 1970: ''Wir lassen uns unsre heute noch gesunde Jugend und unsre freiheitliche westliche Kultur nicht durch solche eindeutig vom Osten gesteuerte Aufweichungstaktik unterminieren und “sturmreif” für den Kommunismus machen.''.
and added that some schools banned the book; Radio Bern canceled a broadcast on it; and bookstores canceled orders; the city authorities determined that the book was not seditious, but with police assurance that they had the power to do so, banned it as posing a danger to minors. His actions revealed latent attitudinal and generational divisions within the party, and he was not re-elected in 1971.[http://de.memoriav.ch/memobase/search/detail.aspx?docid=RJSFDRS_93077691&startrank=1&rankcount=9726 see also] In 1972, he opened his new family medical practice in Basel. ===Activism against miscarriages of justice=== [[File:Hans Martin Sutermeister 1971.jpg|thumb|upright|Of the [[Swiss Posters Collection]]: Sutermeister's election poster for the Bernese [[Gemeinderat (Bern)|Gemeinderat]], 1971.]] In the 1960s, Sutermeister became interested in [[forensic pathology]], and began to involve himself in investigating and attempting to right miscarriages of justice. He traveled widely and wrote analyses on false recognition, intimidation by prison inmates, uncritical acceptance of expert testimony, suggestibility and emotionalism in jurors and psychological errors by judges. His book ''Summa Iniuria'', which treats hundreds of cases, is one of the most thorough German-language works in the field. He concerned himself particularly with the case of [[Jaccoud case|Pierre Jaccoud]], whom he was convinced had been wrongly convicted of murdering Charles Zumbach based on faulty forensic work. At one point Pierre Hegg, the head of the police criminological laboratory, sued him for defamation.[http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-43067286.html "Ein gewisses Lächeln"], ''[[Der Spiegel]]'', 45/1960, 2 November 1960, p. 71 (German). His efforts on behalf of Jaccoud made him a prominent and effective opponent of courtroom injustice, and he went so far as to assemble the funds to hire Horace Mastronardi and other lawyers to appeal Jaccoud's conviction.[[Jürgen Thorwald]], ''Blutiges Geheimnis'', Munich: Droemer Knaur, 1969, {{OCLC|159809005}}, pp. 257-58 (German). Despite his efforts, the case was never reopened. The criminal law expert [[Karl Peters (jurist)|Karl Peters]] puts Sutermeister's ''Summa iniuria'' in the context of the earlier works of [[Erich Sello]], [[Max Alsberg]], [[Albert Hellwig]], [[Max Hirschberg]] and [[Heinrich Jagusch]] and considers him as a "committed fighters for a constitutionally protected Criminal Justice".[[Karl Peters (jurist)|Karl Peters]]. [http://www.reference-global.com/doi/pdf/10.1515/zstw.1976.88.4.978 ''Sutermeister, Hans M.: Summa iniuria. Ein Pitaval der Justizirrtümer. Basel 1976]{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}.'' In: ''Zeitschrift für die gesamte Strafrechtswissenschaft.'' XXVI, vol.88, 1/1976, p.993-995 {{DOI|10.1515/zstw.1976.88.4.978}}. == Bibliography == {{Cleanup|section|reason=totally exagerrated list of published items|date=December 2016}} The '''bibliography of Hans Martin Sutermeister''' includes a fictional novel and around 150 scientific articles, essays and books, some of them [[Investigative journalism]] written by the Swiss writer Hans Martin Sutermeister, pen name Hans Moehrlen (1907–1977). Sutermeister was a prolific writer on topics related to [[psychosomatic medicine]], [[music psychology]] and [[history of medicine]] as well as contemporary Swiss society and cultural criticism, whom [[Karl Peters (jurist)|Karl Peters]] in 2008 declared "a fierce fighter for justice."{{cite book | last =Peters | first = Karl | authorlink = Karl Peters (jurist) | title = Justiz als Schicksal: ein Plädoyer für die andere Seite | publisher = [[De Gruyter]] | year = 1979 | location = Berlin | pages = 192 | language = German | isbn =978-2-01-005712-0}} Sutermeister is best remembered for his contradictory political as a both-left-and-rightwing libertarian-authoritarian presence in local media. Every line of work that he has written since 1942 seeming, directly or indirectly, in favour of a [[monism|monist]] [[Weltanschauung|worldview]]. To that end, Sutermeister used his scientific writing to defend his political convictions, as shown in several book reviews. He first achieved acclaim with his non–fictional books from ''Psychologie und Weltanschauung'' (1944) to ''Schiller als Arzt'' (1955) and cemented his place in local history as one of the greatest Swiss pamphletists with the publication of ''[[Summa Iniuria: Ein Pitaval der Justizirrtümer]]'' shortly before his death. Sutermeister wrote non-fiction—including book reviews, editorials, and investigative journalism—for a variety of Swiss periodicals, mainly [[Public health journal|medical journals]]. He particularly wrote a book-length investigation of [[comprehensive school]]s in Switzerland and another of [[miscarriage of justice|miscarriages of justice]] in the form of ''[[Summa Iniuria: Ein Pitaval der Justizirrtümer]]'', a retrospective of criminal justice mainly in Switzerland and Germany. No attempts have been made until now to comprehensively collect the entirety of his miscellany. === Books === Sutermeister composed one novel, ''Zwischen zwei Welten'', which is autobiographical; it was inspired by his period working as a student during [[Second World War|wartime]]; it records his experiences living and [[wikt:tramping|tramping]] in a town where he later finished his medical studies; the names are partially fictionalized: * {{cite book |author=Moehrlen, Hans (pen name of Hans Martin Sutermeister) |title=Zwischen zwei Welten: Novelle |publisher=Buchdruckerei Mettler & Salz A.G. |location=Bern |year=1942 |isbn=}} (Autobiographic novel, published under the pseudonym "Hans Moehrlen"). 76 pages. Reprint by the [[Swiss National Library]], Bern 2011, {{ISBN|978-3-226-00030-6}}. ::::Book reviews: ::::* [[Carl Heinrich]] in: ''[[Die Gefährten: Monatsschrift für Erkenntnis und Tat]].'' Vol. 9–17, 1947, p. 69. ::::* [[Anton Schaller]]: [https://web.archive.org/web/20131230231911/http://www.seniorweb.ch/type/magazine-column/2012-04-29-zwischen-zwei-welten ''Zwischen zwei Welten: Erinnerung an den Landesring oder was eine kleine Novelle bewirken kann''] Seniorweb.ch, 29 April 2012. Among his [[Non-fiction book]]s are the writings of his [[neopositivism|Neopositivist]] period (1942–1945) which culminates in his article ''Der Neopositivismus als neue Einheitsweltanschauung'' (1945; see below): * ''Nomen atque omen. Friedli, Bern 1942, 92 pages. * {{cite book |author=Sutermeister, Hans Martin |title=Psychologie und Weltanschauung: Wirklichkeitsfragen und ihre Beantwortung nach dem heutigen Stande der Wissenschaft in allgemeinverständlicher Darstellung |publisher=Hans Huber |location=Bern |year=1944 |oclc=602245072 |ASIN=B000SFI7NY}} 184 pages. His insights into [[history of medicine]], literature, and politics (defending in particular [[anti-fascist]], [[liberal socialist]], [[freethought]] and somehow [[anti-communist]] ideas) during the following years. Since his death, many essays have disappeared, with the first attempt at a comprehensive collection being this list. Some of his essays, mainly during his time as member of the [[Ring of Independents]] political party, took the form of [[pamphlet]]s and were published and distributed (by himself) independently. In German-speaking countries, '''Hauptwohnsitz''' ({{lang-en|Main domicile}}) denotes the primary place of residence. In [[Germany]] and [[Austria]], the concept of Hauptwohnsitz has special legal ramifications, primarily involving [[tax]].
In [[Austria]] the Hauptwohnsitz<ref name="hws-oe">[http://www.help.gv.at/Content.Node/99/Seite.990076.html help.gv.at - ''Hauptwohnsitz''] (German language), accessed 10 August 2009</ref> has an important meaning in the context of [[finance|financial]] adjustment between the [[Government of Austria|federation]] and the local [[municipality|municipalities]]. On the basis of the [[census]] determined number of inhabitants with Hauptwohnsitz, the municipality receives its budget from the federal government. Hauptwohnsitze count themselves for a municipality in two regards: By the direct payment per head, and an increase in premiums after exceeding certain thresholds for the number of inhabitants. This leads to frequent censuses to match the budget of a municipality to its number of inhabitants. In fact, many municipalities are negatively affected by this system. The city of [[Graz]], Austria's second largest city, counts about 260,000 registered Hauptwohnsitze, however, almost 300,000 people do have their main residence there, as there are many students still having their Hauptwohnsitz registered in their hometowns. Since those are not taken into account concerning fiscal distribution, Graz faces serious economic problems. Currently there are campaigns trying to motivate students having their Hauptwohnsitz registered there.
The Hauptwohnsitz in [[Germany]] is based on the main center of ones' interest (''Lebensmittelpunkt'').<ref name="mrrg">[http://bundesrecht.juris.de/mrrg/ ''Melderechtsrahmengesetz''] (German language), § 12 (2)</ref> The Hauptwohnsitz is also the place in which one exercises the right to [[Elections in Germany|vote]], and where the [[Municipalities_of_Germany|municipal administration]] issues a citizen's [[German identity card|ID card]] and [[German passport|passport]]. The income tax revenue is split between the federal government, the [[States of Germany|Land]] government and the municipality where the respective taxpayer has their ''Hauptwohnsitz''. Apart from the ''Hauptwohnsitz'' a person can establish multiple secondary places of residence (''Nebenwohnsitze'', sg. ''Nebenwohnsitz'') where they are also registered as residents but do not have a right to vote. A number of German municipalities impose a secondary-residence tax (''Zweitwohnungssteuer'') on persons having such a secondary residence, the rationale for that being that they have to provide services to these persons but do not share in their income tax.
